title: The Story of Joseph
subtitle: Genesis 37-50
description: A Plot Point Analysis for Modern Adaptation

plotPoints.text: Jacob settles in Canaan (the Promised Land) where his father Isaac had lived
Joseph, age 17, works as shepherd with his half-brothers (sons of Bilhah and Zilpah)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph is 17 years old

plotPoints.text: Joseph brings his father a bad report about his brothers' behavior
Israel (Jacob) loves Joseph more than all his other sons because Joseph was born in his old age
Jacob makes Joseph a special long-sleeved robe (coat of many colors)
plotPoints.keyDetail: The famous coat of many colors

plotPoints.text: Brothers hate Joseph because of their father's favoritism - they cannot speak peaceably to him
Joseph dreams that his sheaf of grain rises up while his brothers' sheaves bow down to it
plotPoints.keyDetail: First dream - sheaves bowing

plotPoints.text: Brothers hate him even more for his dream and his words
Joseph has a second dream: the sun, moon, and eleven stars bow down to him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Second dream - celestial bodies bowing

plotPoints.text: Joseph tells his father and brothers - even Jacob rebukes him, asking if the family will bow to him
Brothers are jealous, but Jacob keeps the matter in mind
Brothers go to Shechem to pasture their father's flocks
Israel sends Joseph from the Valley of Hebron to check on his brothers and the flocks
Joseph wanders in the field near Shechem - a man finds him and tells him the brothers went to Dothan
Brothers see Joseph from a distance before he reaches them
Brothers conspire to kill Joseph, calling him 'that dreamer'
plotPoints.keyDetail: They call him 'that dreamer'

plotPoints.text: They plan to throw him in a pit and claim a wild animal devoured him
Reuben (the firstborn) intervenes to save Joseph - suggests throwing him in the pit but not killing him directly
Reuben secretly plans to rescue Joseph and return him to their father
Brothers strip Joseph of his special robe when he arrives
plotPoints.keyDetail: The coat is taken - loss of favored status

plotPoints.text: They throw him into an empty pit (cistern) with no water in it
plotPoints.keyDetail: The pit - first descent

plotPoints.text: Brothers sit down to eat bread while Joseph is in the pit
They see a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead with camels carrying spices, balm, and resin to Egypt
Judah suggests selling Joseph to the Ishmaelites rather than killing him - 'he is our brother, our own flesh'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah proposes the sale

plotPoints.text: Brothers agree to Judah's plan
Midianite traders pass by and pull Joseph from the pit
They sell Joseph to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver
plotPoints.keyDetail: Twenty pieces of silver - the price of betrayal

plotPoints.text: The Ishmaelites take Joseph to Egypt
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph enters Egypt

plotPoints.text: Reuben returns to the pit and discovers Joseph is gone - he tears his clothes in distress
Brothers slaughter a goat and dip Joseph's robe in the blood
They bring the bloodied robe to their father, saying 'We found this - is it your son's robe?'
Jacob recognizes it and concludes a wild animal has devoured Joseph
Jacob tears his clothes, puts on sackcloth, and mourns for his son many days
All his sons and daughters try to comfort him, but he refuses comfort
Jacob says he will go down to Sheol (the grave) mourning for his son
Meanwhile, the Midianites sell Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, Pharaoh's officer and captain of the guard
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph sold to Potiphar

chapters.note: This chapter interrupts Joseph's narrative to tell Judah's story

plotPoints.text: Judah leaves his brothers and visits an Adullamite friend named Hirah
Judah marries a Canaanite woman (daughter of Shua)
She bears three sons: Er, Onan, and Shelah
Judah arranges marriage between Er (his firstborn) and Tamar
Er is wicked in the LORD's sight - the LORD puts him to death
Judah tells Onan to perform levirate marriage duty with Tamar to raise offspring for his brother
Onan refuses to provide offspring - he 'wastes his seed' - displeasing to the LORD
The LORD puts Onan to death as well
Judah tells Tamar to remain a widow in her father's house until Shelah grows up
Judah fears Shelah will die like his brothers, so he doesn't follow through
Time passes - Judah's wife dies, he mourns, then goes to Timnah for sheep shearing
Tamar learns Judah is going to Timnah and realizes Shelah is grown but not given to her
Tamar removes her widow's clothes, covers herself with a veil, and sits at Enaim entrance
Judah sees her, thinks she is a prostitute (her face is covered), and propositions her
Tamar asks what he will give - he promises a young goat from his flock
She demands a pledge until he sends it: his seal, cord, and staff
plotPoints.keyDetail: Seal, cord, and staff - Judah's identity

plotPoints.text: Judah gives her the items and sleeps with her - she becomes pregnant
Tamar removes the veil and returns to her widow's clothes
Judah sends his friend Hirah with a goat to retrieve his pledge - cannot find the woman
Local men say there has been no cult prostitute at Enaim
Three months later, Judah is told 'Tamar your daughter-in-law has prostituted herself and is pregnant'
Judah orders her brought out and burned to death
As she is brought out, Tamar sends Judah his seal, cord, and staff with message: 'I am pregnant by the man who owns these'
Judah recognizes them and declares 'She is more righteous than I, since I did not give her to Shelah'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah's admission of wrongdoing

plotPoints.text: Judah does not sleep with her again
Tamar gives birth to twins - Perez and Zerah (ancestors in the line of King David and Jesus)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Ancestors of David and Jesus

chapters.chapterTitle: Joseph in Potiphar's House and Prison

plotPoints.text: Joseph is taken to Egypt - Potiphar (Pharaoh's officer, captain of guard, an Egyptian) buys him from Ishmaelites
The LORD is with Joseph - he becomes successful
plotPoints.keyDetail: First 'LORD is with Joseph' statement

plotPoints.text: Joseph lives in his Egyptian master's house
Potiphar sees that the LORD is with Joseph and makes everything successful
Joseph finds favor and becomes Potiphar's personal attendant
Potiphar puts Joseph in charge of his household and everything he owns
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph given authority over household

plotPoints.text: The LORD blesses Potiphar's house because of Joseph - blessing on everything in house and field
Potiphar leaves everything in Joseph's care - concerns himself with nothing except the food he eats
Joseph is well-built and handsome
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's appearance noted - sets up next section

plotPoints.text: After some time, Potiphar's wife takes notice of Joseph
She says 'Sleep with me'
Joseph refuses - says his master trusts him with everything except her (his wife)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's first refusal

plotPoints.text: Joseph declares this would be a great evil and sin against God
She speaks to Joseph day after day - he refuses and avoids being near her
One day Joseph goes into the house to do his work - no household servants are inside
She grabs him by his garment saying 'Sleep with me'
Joseph leaves his garment in her hand and flees outside
plotPoints.keyDetail: Second garment taken - this time in righteousness

plotPoints.text: Seeing he left his garment and fled, she calls household servants
She tells them: 'The Hebrew man your master brought came to make a fool of me, but I screamed and he fled, leaving his garment'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Calls him 'Hebrew man' - outsider status

plotPoints.text: She keeps Joseph's garment until Potiphar comes home
She tells Potiphar the same story
Potiphar becomes furious when he hears his wife's story
Potiphar takes Joseph and puts him in prison where the king's prisoners are confined
plotPoints.keyDetail: Second pit - the prison

plotPoints.text: But the LORD is with Joseph in prison - shows him faithful love
plotPoints.keyDetail: Second 'LORD is with Joseph' statement

plotPoints.text: Joseph finds favor with the prison warden
Warden puts all prisoners under Joseph's authority
Joseph manages everything done there
Warden does not check on anything under Joseph's authority because the LORD is with him
The LORD makes everything Joseph does successful
plotPoints.keyDetail: Success even in prison

plotPoints.text: After these events, Pharaoh's cupbearer and baker offend the king of Egypt
Pharaoh is angry with both officials
He puts them in custody in the house of the captain of the guard (same prison as Joseph)
Captain of guard assigns Joseph to them - he serves them
They are in custody for some time
Both men dream on the same night - each dream with its own meaning
Joseph comes to them in the morning and sees they look troubled
They tell him: 'We had dreams but there is no one to interpret them'
Joseph replies: 'Don't interpretations belong to God? Tell me your dreams'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph credits God for interpretation

plotPoints.text: The cupbearer describes his dream: a vine with three branches that budded, blossomed, and produced ripe grapes
He held Pharaoh's cup, took the grapes, squeezed them into the cup, and placed it in Pharaoh's hand
Joseph interprets: 'The three branches are three days'
'In three days Pharaoh will lift up your head and restore you to your position as cupbearer'
Joseph makes a request: 'When things go well for you, remember me and show kindness - mention me to Pharaoh and get me out of this prison'
Joseph explains: 'I was kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews, and even here I have done nothing to deserve being put in this dungeon'
When the baker sees the favorable interpretation, he tells his dream: 'I had three baskets of white bread on my head'
The top basket had all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but birds were eating them
Joseph interprets: 'The three baskets are three days'
'In three days Pharaoh will lift up your head - from you - and hang you on a pole, and the birds will eat your flesh'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Contrast: 'lift up' means death for baker

plotPoints.text: On the third day, Pharaoh's birthday, he gives a feast for all his officials
He lifts up the head of the cupbearer and the baker among his officials
He restores the cupbearer to his position - he again places the cup in Pharaoh's hand
But he hangs the baker - just as Joseph had interpreted to them
Yet the cupbearer does not remember Joseph - he forgets him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph remains forgotten - beginning of two-year wait

plotPoints.text: After two full years, Pharaoh has a dream: He is standing by the Nile
plotPoints.keyDetail: Two years pass - Joseph is about 28 now

plotPoints.text: Seven healthy, well-fed cows come up from the Nile and graze in the reed grass
Seven other cows, ugly and thin, come up from the Nile and stand beside them
The ugly, thin cows eat the healthy, well-fed cows
Then Pharaoh wakes up. He falls asleep again and has a second dream
Seven heads of grain, healthy and good, are growing on a single stalk
Seven thin heads of grain, scorched by the east wind, sprout after them
The thin heads of grain swallow up the seven healthy, full heads
Pharaoh wakes up troubled - it was a dream
In the morning his spirit is troubled, so he summons all the magicians and wise men of Egypt
Pharaoh tells them his dreams, but no one can interpret them
plotPoints.keyDetail: Egyptian wisdom fails

plotPoints.text: The chief cupbearer speaks to Pharaoh: 'Today I remember my faults'
He recalls when Pharaoh was angry with his servants and imprisoned him and the baker
He describes how they both dreamed and a young Hebrew, servant to the captain of the guard, interpreted their dreams
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph identified as 'young Hebrew'

plotPoints.text: 'It turned out just as he interpreted to us - I was restored and the other was hanged'
Pharaoh sends for Joseph, and they quickly bring him from the dungeon
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph brought from dungeon

plotPoints.text: He shaves himself, changes his clothes, and goes to Pharaoh
Pharaoh says to Joseph: 'I have had a dream and no one can interpret it. I have heard you can interpret dreams'
Joseph answers: 'I cannot do it, but God will give Pharaoh a favorable answer'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph credits God, not himself

plotPoints.text: Pharaoh recounts both dreams to Joseph
Joseph tells Pharaoh: 'Pharaoh's dreams mean the same thing. God has revealed to Pharaoh what he is about to do'
'The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good heads are seven years - it is one dream'
'The seven thin and ugly cows that came up after them are seven years, and the seven worthless heads scorched by the east wind are seven years of famine'
'It is just as I told Pharaoh: God has shown Pharaoh what he is about to do'
'Seven years of great abundance are coming throughout the land of Egypt'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Seven years of plenty coming

plotPoints.text: 'But seven years of famine will follow them - all the abundance in Egypt will be forgotten, and the famine will ravage the land'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Seven years of famine following

plotPoints.text: 'The abundance will not be remembered because the famine that follows will be so severe'
'The dream came to Pharaoh twice because the matter has been determined by God, and God will carry it out soon'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Double dream = certainty and soon fulfillment

plotPoints.text: Joseph advises: 'Let Pharaoh look for a discerning and wise man and put him in charge of the land of Egypt'
'Let Pharaoh appoint commissioners over the land to take a fifth of the harvest of Egypt during the seven years of abundance'
plotPoints.keyDetail: 20% tax during abundance

plotPoints.text: 'They should collect all the food of these good years and store up grain under Pharaoh's authority, to be kept in the cities for food'
'This food should be held in reserve for the country, to be used during the seven years of famine that will come upon Egypt, so that the country may not be ruined by the famine'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph proposes salvation plan

plotPoints.text: The plan seems good to Pharaoh and all his officials
Pharaoh asks his officials: 'Can we find anyone like this man, one in whom is the Spirit of God?'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Pharaoh recognizes God's Spirit in Joseph

plotPoints.text: Pharaoh says to Joseph: 'Since God has made all this known to you, there is no one so discerning and wise as you'
'You shall be in charge of my palace, and all my people are to submit to your orders. Only with respect to the throne will I be greater than you'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph made second only to Pharaoh

plotPoints.text: Pharaoh says: 'I hereby put you in charge of the whole land of Egypt'
Pharaoh removes his signet ring and puts it on Joseph's finger
plotPoints.keyDetail: Signet ring = full authority

plotPoints.text: He dresses Joseph in robes of fine linen and puts a gold chain around his neck
plotPoints.keyDetail: Third garment - this one of honor

plotPoints.text: He has Joseph ride in a chariot as his second-in-command, and people shout 'Bow down!' before him
plotPoints.keyDetail: People bowing - first dream fulfilled

plotPoints.text: Pharaoh declares: 'I am Pharaoh, but without your word no one will lift hand or foot in all Egypt'
Pharaoh gives Joseph the name Zaphenath-paneah
plotPoints.keyDetail: Egyptian name meaning 'God speaks and lives'

plotPoints.text: Pharaoh gives him Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, to be his wife
Joseph was thirty years old when he entered Pharaoh's service
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph is 30 - 13 years since pit

plotPoints.text: Joseph goes out from Pharaoh's presence and travels throughout Egypt
During the seven years of abundance the land produces plentifully
Joseph collects all the food produced during those seven years in Egypt and stores it in the cities
He stores up grain like sand of the sea - so much that he stops measuring because it is beyond measure
Before the years of famine, two sons are born to Joseph and Asenath
Joseph names the firstborn Manasseh: 'God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father's household'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Manasseh = 'causing to forget'

plotPoints.text: The second son he names Ephraim: 'God has made me fruitful in the land of my suffering'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Ephraim = 'fruitful' - fruitful in suffering

plotPoints.text: The seven years of abundance in Egypt come to an end
The seven years of famine begin, just as Joseph said
There is famine in all lands, but in Egypt there is food
When all Egypt begins to feel the famine, the people cry to Pharaoh for food
Pharaoh tells all the Egyptians: 'Go to Joseph and do what he tells you'
plotPoints.keyDetail: All Egypt directed to Joseph

plotPoints.text: Joseph opens all the storehouses and sells grain to the Egyptians
And all the world comes to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph, because the famine is severe everywhere
plotPoints.keyDetail: All nations come to Joseph for survival

plotPoints.text: Jacob learns there is grain in Egypt and asks his sons: 'Why do you sit here looking at one another?'
'I have heard there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy some for us, so we may live and not die'
Ten of Joseph's brothers go down to buy grain from Egypt
But Jacob does not send Benjamin, Joseph's brother, with the others because he fears harm might come to him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Benjamin kept back - Jacob's lingering fear

plotPoints.text: Israel's sons are among those who go to buy grain, for there is famine in the land of Canaan also
Joseph is governor of the land - the one who sells grain to all its people
When Joseph's brothers arrive, they bow down to him with their faces to the ground
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers bow - first dream fulfilled exactly

plotPoints.text: Joseph recognizes his brothers, but they do not recognize him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph knows them, they don't know him

plotPoints.text: Joseph remembers his dreams about them and says: 'You are spies! You have come to see where our land is vulnerable'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph remembers his dreams in this moment

plotPoints.text: They answer: 'No, my lord! Your servants have come to buy food'
'We are all sons of one man. Your servants are honest men, not spies'
Joseph insists: 'No! You have come to see where our land is vulnerable'
They reply: 'Your servants are twelve brothers, sons of one man in Canaan. The youngest is now with our father, and one is no more'
plotPoints.keyDetail: 'One is no more' - they admit their crime indirectly

plotPoints.text: Joseph says: 'It is just as I said - you are spies!'
'This is how you will be tested: As surely as Pharaoh lives, you will not leave unless your youngest brother comes here'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph demands to see Benjamin

plotPoints.text: 'Send one of you to get your brother while the rest are kept in prison, so your words may be tested'
He puts them all in custody for three days
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers experience prison - taste of Joseph's suffering

plotPoints.text: On the third day, Joseph says: 'Do this and you will live, for I fear God'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph reveals his fear of God

plotPoints.text: 'If you are honest, let one brother remain here in prison while the rest go and take grain back for your starving households'
'But you must bring your youngest brother to me so your words can be verified and you may not die'
They agree to this
They say to one another: 'Surely we are being punished for our brother. We saw his anguish when he pleaded with us, but we would not listen - that's why this distress has come on us'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers confess - Joseph pleaded with them

plotPoints.text: Reuben replies: 'Didn't I tell you not to sin against the boy? But you wouldn't listen! Now we must account for his blood'
They do not realize Joseph understands them, since he is using an interpreter
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph understands everything they say

plotPoints.text: Joseph turns away from them and weeps
plotPoints.keyDetail: First time Joseph weeps hearing their confession

plotPoints.text: Then he turns back and speaks to them again, and has Simeon taken and bound before their eyes
plotPoints.keyDetail: Simeon chosen (perhaps most aggressive against Joseph?)

plotPoints.text: Joseph orders his servants to fill the brothers' bags with grain, return each man's silver to his sack, and give them provisions for the journey
They load the grain on their donkeys and depart
At the place where they stop for the night, one opens his sack to feed his donkey and sees his silver in the top of the sack
He says to his brothers: 'My silver has been returned! Here it is in my sack!'
Their hearts sink and they turn trembling to one another: 'What is this that God has done to us?'
plotPoints.keyDetail: They recognize God's involvement

plotPoints.text: When they return to Jacob in Canaan, they tell him all that happened
'The man who is lord over the land spoke harshly to us and treated us as spies'
'We told him we are honest men, not spies - twelve brothers, sons of one father. One is no more, and the youngest is now with our father in Canaan'
'The man said to bring our youngest brother to prove we are honest, then we could have Simeon back and trade freely in the land'
As they empty their sacks, each man's pouch of silver is in his sack
When they and their father see the pouches of silver, they are afraid
Jacob says: 'You have deprived me of my children. Joseph is no more and Simeon is no more, and now you want to take Benjamin. Everything is against me!'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob's cry of loss - 'Everything is against me!'

plotPoints.text: Reuben says: 'You may put both my sons to death if I do not bring Benjamin back to you. Entrust him to my care and I will bring him back'
But Jacob replies: 'My son will not go down there with you. His brother is dead and he is the only one left. If harm comes to him on the journey, you will bring my gray head down to Sheol in sorrow'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob refuses - still mourning Joseph

chapters.chapterTitle: The Brothers' Second Journey with Benjamin

plotPoints.text: The famine in the land is severe
When they finish eating the grain from Egypt, Jacob tells them 'Go back and buy us some food'
Judah reminds him: 'The man specifically warned us: You will not see me again unless your brother is with you'
'If you will send Benjamin, we will go buy food. But if not, we will not go, for the man said we cannot see him without our brother'
Israel asks 'Why did you cause me this trouble by telling the man you had another brother?'
They explain 'The man kept asking about us and our family: Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?'
'We answered him accordingly. How could we know he would say Bring your brother here?'
Judah says to Israel 'Send the boy with me. We will go at once so that we may live and not die - we, you, and our dependents'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah emerges as leader and spokesman

plotPoints.text: 'I will be responsible for him. You can hold me personally accountable. If I do not bring him back, I will be guilty before you forever'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah's pledge - complete opposite of his past

plotPoints.text: 'If we had not delayed, we could have come back twice by now'
Israel agrees and instructs them to take gifts: some of the best products - balm, honey, aromatic gum, resin, pistachios, almonds
'Take twice as much silver - return the silver found in your bags, perhaps it was a mistake'
'Take your brother and go back to the man at once'
Israel prays: 'May God Almighty grant you compassion before the man so he releases your other brother and Benjamin to you'
'As for me, if I am bereaved, I am bereaved'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob's ultimate surrender to God's will

plotPoints.text: The men take the gifts, double the amount of silver, and Benjamin
They make their way down to Egypt and stand before Joseph
When Joseph sees Benjamin with them, he tells his steward 'Take the men to my house, slaughter an animal and prepare it, for they will eat with me at noon'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph sees Benjamin and immediately plans feast

plotPoints.text: The steward does as Joseph says and brings them to Joseph's house
The men are afraid because they are taken to Joseph's house
They think 'We have been brought here because of the silver returned in our bags. He intends to attack us, seize us, and make us slaves'
They approach Joseph's steward and speak to him at the doorway
They explain they came before to buy food, and when they opened their bags, each man's silver was there
'We have brought it back with us and additional silver to buy food. We don't know who put the silver in our bags'
The steward says 'Everything is all right. Don't be afraid. Your God and the God of your father has put treasure in your bags. I received your silver'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Steward credits their God - Joseph's influence

plotPoints.text: The steward brings Simeon out to them
He brings the men into Joseph's house, gives them water to wash their feet, and feeds their donkeys
They prepare their gift for Joseph's arrival at noon, since they hear they will eat there
Joseph comes home - they bring him the gift and bow to the ground before him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers bow again - repeated fulfillment

plotPoints.text: He asks how they are and 'Is your elderly father you told me about well? Is he still alive?'
They answer 'Your servant our father is well. He is still alive' and bow down to honor him
Joseph looks up and sees Benjamin, his mother's son
plotPoints.keyDetail: Benjamin specifically identified as 'his mother's son'

plotPoints.text: He asks 'Is this your youngest brother you told me about?' and says 'May God be gracious to you, my son'
Joseph hurries out because he is overcome with emotion for his brother
plotPoints.keyDetail: Second time Joseph weeps

plotPoints.text: He goes to a private room and weeps
He washes his face, regains control, and comes out saying 'Serve the meal'
They serve him by himself, the brothers by themselves, and the Egyptians eating with him by themselves
(Egyptians cannot eat with Hebrews - it is detestable to them)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Cultural context - separation of peoples

plotPoints.text: The brothers are seated before Joseph in order from firstborn to youngest
They look at each other in astonishment
plotPoints.keyDetail: How could he know their birth order?

plotPoints.text: Portions are served from Joseph's table - Benjamin's portion is five times larger than anyone else's
plotPoints.keyDetail: Benjamin given five times more - testing brothers' jealousy

plotPoints.text: They eat and drink freely with Joseph

chapters.chapterTitle: The Final Test - Joseph's Silver Cup

plotPoints.text: Joseph commands his steward: 'Fill the men's bags with as much food as they can carry'
'Put each one's silver at the top of his bag'
'Put my cup, the silver one, at the top of the youngest one's bag along with his grain silver'
plotPoints.keyDetail: The silver cup - Joseph's personal item planted

plotPoints.text: The steward does as Joseph tells him
At morning light, the men are sent off with their donkeys
They have not gone far from the city when Joseph tells his steward: 'Get up and pursue those men'
'When you overtake them, say: Why have you repaid evil for good? Isn't this the cup my master drinks from and uses for divination? What you have done is wrong'
The steward overtakes them and repeats these words
Brothers respond 'Why does my lord say these things? Your servants could not possibly do such a thing'
'We even brought back the silver from our bags - why would we steal silver or gold from your master's house?'
'If it is found with one of your servants, he must die, and the rest of us will become my lord's slaves'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers make death oath - echoes Jacob's rash oath

plotPoints.text: Steward says 'Let it be as you say, but only the one with whom it is found will be my slave. The rest will be blameless'
Each man quickly lowers his sack to the ground and opens it
The steward searches, beginning with the oldest and ending with the youngest
plotPoints.keyDetail: Order builds suspense - Benjamin searched last

plotPoints.text: The cup is found in Benjamin's sack
plotPoints.keyDetail: The cup found - moment of crisis

plotPoints.text: They tear their clothes in grief
Each man loads his donkey and they return to the city
plotPoints.keyDetail: All return - they don't abandon Benjamin

plotPoints.text: Judah and his brothers enter Joseph's house while he is still there
They fall to the ground before him
Joseph asks 'What is this you have done? Didn't you know a man like me could uncover the truth by divination?'
Judah replies 'What can we say to my lord? How can we plead? How can we justify ourselves?'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah speaks for all - leadership role

plotPoints.text: 'God has exposed your servants' iniquity. We are now my lord's slaves - both we and the one in whose possession the cup was found'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah recognizes God's hand - their past sin exposed

plotPoints.text: Joseph says 'I would never do such a thing. The man in whose possession the cup was found will be my slave. The rest of you can go in peace to your father'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Final test - will they abandon Benjamin?

plotPoints.text: Judah approaches Joseph and says 'My lord, please let your servant speak personally to you. Do not be angry with your servant'
Judah recounts how Joseph asked if they had a father or brother
They told him about their father, an old man, and a younger brother, child of his old age
'That brother's full brother is dead. He alone is left of his mother's sons, and his father loves him'
plotPoints.keyDetail: 'Full brother is dead' - speaking of Joseph to Joseph

plotPoints.text: Joseph told them to bring the brother so he could see him
They explained the boy cannot leave his father - if he does, his father will die
But Joseph insisted they would not see him again unless the youngest brother came
When they returned to their father, they reported Joseph's words
Their father told them to go buy more food
They said they couldn't go unless Benjamin went with them
Their father reminded them his wife bore him two sons
'One left me, and I said he must have been torn to pieces. I have never seen him again'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob still believes Joseph was torn by beasts

plotPoints.text: 'If you take this one from me too and anything happens to him, you will bring my gray hairs down to Sheol in sorrow'
Judah explains he became surety for the boy - 'If I do not bring him back, I will be guilty before my father forever'
'Now please let your servant remain here as my lord's slave instead of the boy'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah offers himself - complete transformation

plotPoints.text: 'Let him go back with his brothers'
'For how can I go back to my father without the boy? I could not bear to see the grief that would overwhelm my father'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah's climactic plea - he has truly changed

plotPoints.text: Joseph can no longer control himself before all his attendants
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph reaches his emotional limit

plotPoints.text: He calls out 'Send everyone away from me!'
No one is with Joseph when he reveals himself to his brothers
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph protects his brothers' dignity - sends Egyptians away

plotPoints.text: He weeps so loudly that the Egyptians hear it, and Pharaoh's household hears about it
plotPoints.keyDetail: Third and most intense weeping

plotPoints.text: Joseph says to his brothers 'I am Joseph! Is my father still living?'
plotPoints.keyDetail: The moment - 'I am Joseph!'

plotPoints.text: His brothers cannot answer him because they are terrified in his presence
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers terrified - they recognize him and remember their crime

plotPoints.text: Joseph says 'Please, come near me' - they come near
He says 'I am Joseph, your brother, the one you sold into Egypt'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph states the truth plainly - 'you sold'

plotPoints.text: 'And now don't be grieved or angry with yourselves for selling me here'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Immediate forgiveness offered

plotPoints.text: 'Because God sent me ahead of you to preserve life'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's theology - God sent me

plotPoints.text: 'For the famine has been in the land these two years, and there will be five more years without plowing or harvesting'
'God sent me ahead of you to establish you as a remnant within the land and to keep you alive by a great deliverance'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Remnant theology - preserving the covenant line

plotPoints.text: 'Therefore it was not you who sent me here, but God'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's famous statement - God's sovereignty over evil

plotPoints.text: 'He has made me a father to Pharaoh, lord of his entire household, and ruler over all the land of Egypt'
Joseph throws his arms around Benjamin and weeps, and Benjamin weeps on his shoulder
plotPoints.keyDetail: Embraces Benjamin - his full brother

plotPoints.text: Joseph kisses each of his brothers and weeps over them
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph kisses all his brothers - complete reconciliation

plotPoints.text: After this, his brothers talk with him
plotPoints.keyDetail: They can finally speak - barrier of guilt removed

plotPoints.text: 'Return quickly to my father and say: This is what your son Joseph says - God has made me lord of all Egypt'
'Come down to me without delay'
'You can settle in the land of Goshen and be near me - you, your children and grandchildren, your flocks, herds, and all you have'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Goshen offered - fertile land

plotPoints.text: 'There I will sustain you, for there will be five more years of famine. Otherwise you, your household, and everything you have will become destitute'
'Look! Your eyes and my brother Benjamin's eyes can see that it is I, Joseph, who am speaking to you'
'Tell my father about all my glory in Egypt and about all you have seen. And bring my father here quickly'
When the news reaches Pharaoh's palace that Joseph's brothers have come, Pharaoh and his servants are pleased
plotPoints.keyDetail: Pharaoh pleased - Joseph's honor extends to family

plotPoints.text: Pharaoh tells Joseph 'Say to your brothers: Load your animals and go on back to the land of Canaan'
'Get your father and your families and come back to me. I will give you the best of the land of Egypt, and you can eat from the richness of the land'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Pharaoh offers the best land

plotPoints.text: 'You are also commanded to tell them: Take wagons from the land of Egypt for your dependents and your wives and bring your father here'
'Do not be concerned about your belongings, for the best of all the land of Egypt is yours'
The sons of Israel do this
Joseph gives them wagons as Pharaoh commanded, and supplies for the journey
He gives each of them changes of clothes, but to Benjamin he gives 300 pieces of silver and five changes of clothes
plotPoints.keyDetail: Benjamin receives special portion - no jealousy from brothers

plotPoints.text: He sends his father ten donkeys carrying Egypt's best products and ten female donkeys loaded with grain, food, and provisions
Joseph sends his brothers off and says to them 'Don't argue on the way'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph knows his brothers - warns against blame and arguing

plotPoints.text: They go up from Egypt and come to their father Jacob in Canaan
They tell him 'Joseph is still alive, and he is ruler over all the land of Egypt'
plotPoints.keyDetail: The message delivered - Joseph lives!

plotPoints.text: Jacob is stunned - he does not believe them
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob's initial disbelief - years of grief

plotPoints.text: They tell him everything Joseph said to them
When Jacob sees the wagons Joseph sent to transport him, his spirit revives
plotPoints.keyDetail: Wagons = proof - Jacob's spirit revives

plotPoints.text: Israel says 'Enough! My son Joseph is still alive. I will go to see him before I die'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob's response - 'Enough!' - he believes and will go

parts.partTitle: Settlement in Egypt and Final Days

plotPoints.text: Israel sets out with all his possessions
When he reaches Beersheba, he offers sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob stops to worship before entering Egypt

plotPoints.text: That night God speaks to Israel in a vision: 'Jacob, Jacob!'
Jacob answers 'Here I am'
God says 'I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt'
plotPoints.keyDetail: God tells Jacob not to fear Egypt

plotPoints.text: 'For I will make you into a great nation there'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Egypt is where Israel becomes a nation

plotPoints.text: 'I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also bring you back'
plotPoints.keyDetail: God promises to bring them back - foreshadows Exodus

plotPoints.text: 'Joseph will close your eyes'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob will die with Joseph present

plotPoints.text: Jacob leaves Beersheba - his sons transport him in the wagons Pharaoh sent
They take their livestock and possessions acquired in Canaan
Jacob brings all his offspring to Egypt
[Detailed genealogy follows - 70 people total go to Egypt]
plotPoints.keyDetail: 70 people enter Egypt - symbolic number

plotPoints.text: Jacob sends Judah ahead to Joseph to prepare the way before him to Goshen
plotPoints.keyDetail: Judah sent ahead - his leadership role continues

plotPoints.text: When they arrive in Goshen, Joseph hitches his chariot and goes to meet his father Israel
Joseph presents himself to him, throws his arms around him, and weeps for a long time
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph weeps on his father's neck - their reunion

plotPoints.text: Israel says to Joseph 'At last I can die, now that I have seen your face and know you are still alive'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob's life goal achieved - seeing Joseph alive

plotPoints.text: Joseph tells his brothers and father's family 'I will go up and inform Pharaoh'
'I will tell him: My brothers and my father's family, who were in Canaan, have come to me'
'The men are shepherds; they also raise livestock. They have brought their flocks and herds and all that they have'
Joseph instructs them: 'When Pharaoh addresses you and asks What is your occupation?'
'You are to say: Your servants, both we and our fathers, have raised livestock from our youth until now'
'Then you will be allowed to settle in the land of Goshen, since all shepherds are detestable to Egyptians'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Shepherds detestable to Egyptians - ensures separation in Goshen

chapters.chapterTitle: Settlement in Goshen and Joseph's Administration

plotPoints.text: Joseph goes and tells Pharaoh 'My father and my brothers have come from Canaan with their sheep and cattle and all they own, and now they are in Goshen'
He takes five of his brothers and presents them to Pharaoh
Pharaoh asks them 'What is your occupation?'
They answer 'Your servants, both we and our fathers, are shepherds'
'We have come to stay in the land for a while because there is no pasture for your servants' sheep, since the famine is severe in Canaan'
'Now please let your servants settle in the land of Goshen'
Pharaoh says to Joseph 'Your father and brothers have come to you'
'The land of Egypt is before you; settle your father and brothers in the best part of the land'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Pharaoh offers the best land

plotPoints.text: 'Let them live in the land of Goshen. If you know of any capable men among them, put them in charge of my livestock'
Joseph brings his father Jacob and presents him to Pharaoh
Jacob blesses Pharaoh
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob blesses Pharaoh - the lesser blessed by the greater

plotPoints.text: Pharaoh asks Jacob 'How many years have you lived?'
Jacob says 'My pilgrimage has lasted 130 years'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob is 130 years old

plotPoints.text: 'My years have been few and hard, not reaching the years my fathers lived during their pilgrimages'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob reflects on his difficult life

plotPoints.text: Jacob blesses Pharaoh again and departs from his presence
Joseph settles his father and brothers in Egypt and gives them property in the best part of the land (Rameses)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Settled in Rameses/Goshen

plotPoints.text: Joseph provides his father, brothers, and all his father's family with food for their dependents
There is no food in all the land - the famine is very severe
Egypt and Canaan are exhausted by the famine
Joseph collects all the silver in Egypt and Canaan in exchange for grain
Joseph brings the silver to Pharaoh's palace
When the silver runs out, all the Egyptians come to Joseph saying 'Give us food. Why should we die here in front of you? The silver is gone'
Joseph says 'Give me your livestock. Since the silver is gone, I will give you food in exchange for your livestock'
They bring their livestock to Joseph - he gives them food in exchange for horses, sheep, goats, cattle, and donkeys
He provides them with food that year in exchange for all their livestock
When that year is over, they come the next year saying 'We cannot hide from our lord that the silver is gone and all our livestock belongs to you'
'There is nothing left for our lord except our bodies and our land'
'Why should we die here in front of you - both us and our land? Buy us and our land in exchange for food'
'Then we with our land will become Pharaoh's slaves. Give us seed so we can live and not die, and so the land won't become desolate'
Joseph buys all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh
Every Egyptian sells his field because the famine is so severe
The land becomes Pharaoh's
Joseph moves the people to the cities from one end of Egypt to the other
The only land Joseph doesn't buy is the priests' land - they receive rations from Pharaoh and live off what he gives them
Joseph says to the people 'Understand today that I have acquired you and your land for Pharaoh'
'Here is seed for you. Sow it in the land'
'At harvest, give a fifth to Pharaoh, and four-fifths will be yours for seed and food'
plotPoints.keyDetail: 20% tax established - generous by ancient standards

plotPoints.text: They say 'You have saved our lives. We have found favor with you, our lord. We will be Pharaoh's slaves'
Joseph makes it a law still in effect today: a fifth of the produce belongs to Pharaoh (except the priests' land)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Law lasting to Moses' time

plotPoints.text: Israel settles in the land of Goshen - they acquire property, are fruitful, and multiply greatly
plotPoints.keyDetail: Israel multiplies in Goshen - beginning of becoming a nation

plotPoints.text: Jacob lives in Egypt seventeen years - his life span is 147 years
plotPoints.keyDetail: 17 years in Egypt - same length as Joseph's youth with him

plotPoints.text: When the time approaches for Israel to die, he calls his son Joseph
He says 'If I have found favor with you, put your hand under my thigh and promise me you will deal kindly and faithfully with me'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Hand under thigh - ancient oath gesture

plotPoints.text: 'Do not bury me in Egypt'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob wants burial in Promised Land

plotPoints.text: 'When I rest with my fathers, carry me away from Egypt and bury me in their burial place'
Joseph answers 'I will do what you have asked'
Jacob says 'Swear to me,' and Joseph swears to him
Israel bows at the head of his bed
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob worships - peace knowing promise secured

plotPoints.text: After these events, Joseph is told 'Your father is ill'
Joseph takes his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim with him
Jacob is told 'Your son Joseph has come to you'
Israel summons his strength and sits up in bed
Jacob tells Joseph 'God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in Canaan and blessed me'
'He said I will make you fruitful and numerous; I will make many nations from you, and will give this land to your future offspring as an eternal possession'
Jacob says 'Your two sons born to you in Egypt before I came are now mine - Ephraim and Manasseh belong to me just as Reuben and Simeon do'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's sons adopted as Jacob's - become tribes of Israel

plotPoints.text: 'Children born to you after them will be yours and listed under their brothers' names'
Jacob recalls Rachel's death: 'When I was returning from Paddan, Rachel died near me in Canaan on the way. I buried her there'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob still grieves Rachel - speaks of her burial

plotPoints.text: Israel sees Joseph's sons and asks 'Who are these?'
Joseph says 'They are my sons God has given me here'
Israel says 'Bring them to me so I can bless them'
Israel's eyes are weak from old age - he can hardly see
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob nearly blind like Isaac was

plotPoints.text: Joseph brings them close - Israel kisses and embraces them
Israel says to Joseph 'I never expected to see your face again, but now God has even let me see your offspring'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob's gratitude - beyond hope to see Joseph's sons

plotPoints.text: Joseph takes them from Israel's knees and bows with his face to the ground
Joseph positions them so Ephraim is on his left (toward Israel's right) and Manasseh on his right (toward Israel's left)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph positions Manasseh (firstborn) toward right hand

plotPoints.text: Israel stretches out his right hand and puts it on Ephraim's head (though he is younger)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob crosses his hands - deliberate reversal

plotPoints.text: Israel puts his left hand on Manasseh's head, crossing his hands intentionally
plotPoints.keyDetail: Intentional crossing - not accidental

plotPoints.text: He blesses Joseph: 'May the God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked, the God who has been my shepherd all my life, the angel who has redeemed me from all harm - may he bless these boys'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Beautiful blessing - God as shepherd and redeemer

plotPoints.text: 'May they be called by my name and the names of my fathers Abraham and Isaac, and may they grow to be numerous within the land'
Joseph sees his father placing his right hand on Ephraim's head and is displeased
Joseph takes his father's hand to move it from Ephraim's head to Manasseh's
Joseph says 'Not that way, my father! This one is the firstborn. Put your right hand on his head'
But his father refuses: 'I know, my son, I know. He too will become a people and he too will be great'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob knows what he's doing - prophetic purpose

plotPoints.text: 'Nevertheless, his younger brother will be greater than he, and his offspring will become a populous nation'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Ephraim will be greater - pattern continues

plotPoints.text: He blesses them that day with the words: 'The nation Israel will invoke blessings by you, saying, May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh'
plotPoints.keyDetail: This becomes the blessing formula for children

plotPoints.text: He puts Ephraim before Manasseh
Israel says to Joseph 'I am about to die, but God will be with you and will bring you back to the land of your fathers'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Promise of return to Canaan

plotPoints.text: 'I am giving you one portion more than your brothers - the portion I took from the Amorites with my sword and bow'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph receives double portion through his two sons

plotPoints.text: Jacob calls his sons together: 'Gather around so I can tell you what will happen to you in the days to come'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Prophetic blessings for end times

plotPoints.text: Reuben: Firstborn but unstable, will not excel (because of his sin with Bilhah)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Reuben loses firstborn privilege due to sin

plotPoints.text: Simeon and Levi: Instruments of violence, will be scattered in Israel (because of Shechem massacre)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Simeon and Levi judged for Shechem massacre

plotPoints.text: Judah: A lion's cub; the scepter will not depart from Judah until Shiloh comes (Messianic prophecy)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Messianic prophecy - scepter and Shiloh (Messiah)

plotPoints.text: Zebulun: Will live by the seashore and be a harbor for ships
Issachar: A strong donkey, will submit to forced labor
Dan: Will judge his people, will be a snake by the road
Gad: Will be attacked by raiders but will attack their heels
Asher: His food will be rich, will provide royal delicacies
Naphtali: A doe set free, bears beautiful fawns
Joseph: A fruitful vine near a spring; archers attacked him but his bow remained steady
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's blessing - attacked but prevailed

plotPoints.text: Joseph receives extensive blessings: blessings of heaven, deep springs, breast and womb
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph receives most extensive blessing

plotPoints.text: Joseph's blessings surpass the blessings of the ancient mountains - they will rest on the head of the prince among his brothers
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph called 'prince among his brothers'

plotPoints.text: Benjamin: A ravenous wolf; in the morning devours prey, in the evening divides plunder
These are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said when he blessed them
He blessed them, each according to his appropriate blessing
plotPoints.keyDetail: Each receives appropriate blessing

plotPoints.text: Jacob commands them: 'I am about to be gathered to my people'
'Bury me with my fathers in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite'
'The cave in the field of Machpelah near Mamre in Canaan, which Abraham purchased as burial property'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Cave of Machpelah - family burial place

plotPoints.text: 'Abraham and Sarah are buried there, Isaac and Rebekah are buried there, and I buried Leah there'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Four generations buried there - Leah his wife

plotPoints.text: When Jacob finishes instructing his sons, he draws his feet into the bed
He takes his last breath and is gathered to his people
plotPoints.keyDetail: Jacob dies peacefully after blessing sons

plotPoints.text: Joseph throws himself on his father, weeps over him, and kisses him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's grief for his father

plotPoints.text: Joseph commands his servants who are physicians to embalm his father
They embalm Israel - it takes forty days (the time required for embalming)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Forty days for embalming - Egyptian practice

plotPoints.text: The Egyptians mourn for him seventy days
plotPoints.keyDetail: Seventy days mourning - near royal honors

plotPoints.text: When the days of mourning pass, Joseph speaks to Pharaoh's household
'If I have found favor with you, tell Pharaoh that my father made me take an oath: I am about to die. You must bury me in the tomb I made for myself in Canaan'
'Now let me go and bury my father. Then I will return'
Pharaoh says 'Go and bury your father in keeping with your oath'
Joseph goes to bury his father - all Pharaoh's servants, the elders of his household, and all the elders of Egypt go with him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Egyptian officials accompany - great honor

plotPoints.text: Joseph's entire family, his brothers, and his father's family accompany him
Only their dependents, flocks, and herds are left in Goshen
Horses and chariots go with him - it is a very impressive procession
plotPoints.keyDetail: Massive funeral procession with chariots

plotPoints.text: They reach the threshing floor of Atad beyond the Jordan
They hold a very solemn ceremony and Joseph mourns seven days for his father
plotPoints.keyDetail: Seven-day mourning at Atad

plotPoints.text: The Canaanite inhabitants see the mourning and say 'This is a solemn mourning by the Egyptians'
Therefore the place is named Abel-mizraim (mourning of Egypt)
plotPoints.keyDetail: Place named for Egyptian mourning

plotPoints.text: Jacob's sons do for him what he commanded
They carry him to Canaan and bury him in the cave of Machpelah
Abraham had purchased the cave as burial property from Ephron the Hittite
After burying his father, Joseph returns to Egypt with his brothers and all who went with him

sections.sectionTitle: The Brothers' Fear and Joseph's Forgiveness

plotPoints.text: When Joseph's brothers see their father is dead, they say 'If Joseph holds a grudge against us, he will certainly pay us back for all the suffering we caused him'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers fear Joseph's revenge after father dies

plotPoints.text: They send a message to Joseph: 'Before he died your father gave a command'
'Say to Joseph: Please forgive your brothers' transgression and their sin - the suffering they caused you'
'Therefore, please forgive the transgression of the servants of the God of your father'
Joseph weeps when their message comes to him
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph weeps - hurt they still fear him

plotPoints.text: His brothers come and bow down before him: 'We are your slaves'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Brothers bow - final fulfillment of dreams

plotPoints.text: Joseph says to them 'Don't be afraid. Am I in the place of God?'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's humility - only God judges

plotPoints.text: 'You planned evil against me; God planned it for good to bring about the present result - the survival of many people'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Genesis 50:20 - Joseph's famous statement of God's sovereignty

plotPoints.text: 'Therefore don't be afraid. I will take care of you and your children'
Joseph reassures and comforts them
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph speaks kindly - complete forgiveness

plotPoints.text: Joseph and his father's family remain in Egypt
Joseph lives 110 years
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph lives 110 - ideal lifespan in Egyptian thought

plotPoints.text: He sees Ephraim's sons to the third generation
The sons of Machir son of Manasseh are recognized by Joseph
Joseph says to his brothers 'I am about to die, but God will certainly come to your aid'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's death announcement and faith

plotPoints.text: 'He will bring you up from this land to the land he swore to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph prophesies the Exodus

plotPoints.text: Joseph makes the sons of Israel take an oath: 'When God comes to your aid, you are to carry my bones up from here'
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's bones to be carried to Promised Land

plotPoints.text: Joseph dies at the age of 110
They embalm him and place him in a coffin in Egypt
plotPoints.keyDetail: Joseph's body waits in Egypt for Exodus

plotPoints.text: [Joseph's bones are later carried out of Egypt during the Exodus - Exodus 13:19; Joshua 24:32]
plotPoints.keyDetail: Note: Fulfilled 400 years later in the Exodus
